Title: The GOP problem
Article:
Rising vegetable prices have driven consumer inflation to new highs. Get agricultural management back on track

The dramatic increase in vegetable prices this winter, particularly of core products such as garlic, onions and potatoes (GOP), is finally reflecting on inflation statistics. The Government’s own data, released by the National Statistical Office (NSO), has confirmed our worst fears of not just a slowdown but a guttural halt as retail inflation rose by 7.35 per cent last December, which is the highest since July 2014. This can be attributed to a significant rise in food prices, which saw a marked rise from 10.01 per cent in November to 14.12 per cent in December last year. This points to various problems for the Government and the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). The latter has little wiggle room for rate cuts and can do little to spur economic activity. This is actually the first time that the relatively new Monetary Policy Committee (MPC), that adjusts interest rates, will face such a challenge. Until now, the MPC has moved them downward in an effort to boost the economy. Already, banks are desperately trying to repair their loan books that are crippled by non-performing assets (NPAs) and consumers are not biting for real estate loans. Increasing rates to control inflation and spending will only drive consumer spending further downwards, putting the economy under even more pressure. But there is also that other issue of produce management. Over the past few years, the Government has for the large part stabilised food prices with smart management of produce ever since it got burnt by rising pulse prices a few years ago. But this year, the price of onion has seemed to belie expectations. There has been a four-fold increase in the rate of this staple food since June last. This, coupled with an equal rise in garlic and potatoes and other vegetables, has seemingly caught everyone — from everyday consumers to the Government — completely off the guard.

But the GOP problem, as we have termed the situation, is making a “bad” scenario even “worse.” With the economy in the doldrums, job creation at multi-year lows and consumer demand collapsing, the Government finds itself on a sticky wicket. While crop and produce management can be better managed in the coming seasons — the winter of 2019-2020 can be seen as an aberration — getting demand to pick up again is a challenge, particularly with the Government’s ability for limited spending. The Narendra Modi-led Government has ambitious social welfare schemes and they have cost money. Until the economy gets going again, the funds to keep such spending going will also be constrained. The Budget is on its way in a few weeks time. While bureaucrats in the Finance Ministry are working overtime, can the Government really afford an income tax rate cut, as many believe? There is a significant amount of anger in the general population, one that has manifested itself in the anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) protests, which have for the large part been contained. But the Government and its advisors must be acutely aware that things are on a knife-edge. Pretending that everything is normal will not help. It will be of help if the Government seeks the advice of in-house experts on prevailing matters to get going. For now, it has to manage produce prices and understand that while spud prices may not bring the people on the streets today, tomorrow tomato prices or something else just might.

Title: Police commissioner system won’t check crimes: Akihlesh
Article:
Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav flayed the Yogi Adityanath government for introducing police commissionerate system in the state.

“Nothing will change and the crime graph will not go down with new experiments on daily basis. The police commissioner system will make no impact in checking the crimes by merely changing and appointing new officers,” the SP chief said.

“It’s a confession of failure by Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath that he has failed to check crimes even after three years in office. There is no let-up in heinous crime incidents like rape, murder, loot & dacoity, and abductions,” Yadav said.

Terming the police commissioner system yet another gimmick by the BJP government, Akhilesh said: “The BJP government has introduced the police commissioner system only to divert the attention of people who are at the receiving end of police repression.”

On Tuesday, Akhilesh met several delegations of sportspersons and political leaders. He asked them to pull up their socks for the victory of Samajwadi Party and enable it to form the government in UP after the 2022 assembly elections. He alleged that the sole agenda of the BJP was to divide the society on caste and communal grounds and cause polarisation of people on religious lines. He said time has come to get rid of the divisive politics of BJP and bring a new government which would work for all sections of the society irrespective of caste and creed.

Title: Police commissioner system a gimmick: Lallu
Article:
Uttar Pradesh Congress president, Ajay Kumar Lallu on Tuesday flayed Yogi Adityanath government’s move to introduce police commissionerate system in Lucknow and Noida terming it yet another step to hide the failure of his government on the law and order front.

“Besides the rising cases of crime against women with UP almost on top in terms of cases of sexual assault against women, the manner in which the state government failed to control violence during the recent anti-CAA protests and Lucknow witnessing arson and stone-pelting, it is evident that the government has completely failed to deliver on the law and order front,” Lallu said. He claimed introducing police commissioner system was a ploy to divert people’s attention from government’s failures.

Lallu further claimed that even the Supreme Court observed recently that there was ‘jungle raj’ prevailing in UP. “The blue-eyed officers of Adityanath holding key posts have been found to be indulging in sex chats, transfer-posting rackets and large-scale corruption, so the easiest way for the Adityanath government was to come out clean and hence the police commissioner system gimmick,” he alleged.

“The personal conduct of IPS officers is in question after the letter of former Noida SSP Vaibhav Krishna, found involved in sex chat, pointed how some senior IPS officers were minting money in transfers and postings under government’s patronage”, Lallu said, claiming that instead of going for an in-depth enquiry, Yogi showed more trust in IPS officers and introduced new policing system in Lucknow and Noida.

Lallu claimed that until the political interference of the government ended, no system could deliver on the law and order front by mere transfer of some powers.

He also pointed out that even the police commissionerate system was just an eyewash as the power to issue excise and arms licences still rests with the district magistrates and only magisterial power related to law and order has been given to the officers posted in Lucknow and Noida.

Title: Newborn mauled to death by dog in hospital; probe ordered
Article:
The district authorities in Farrukhabad have ordered a probe into a shocking incident in which a newborn was allegedly mauled to death by a dog inside the operation theatre of a private hospital on Monday.

District Magistrate Manvendra Singh said on Tuesday that an FIR has been registered and a probe ordered on the complaint of the newborn’s family.

Chief Medical Officer (CMO) Chandra Shekhar said the hospital has been sealed and a probe into the incident ordered. Family members of the neworn alleged that they noticed the hospital staff shooing away a dog from the operation theatre and soon afterwards, they were told the baby boy, born just two hours ago, was dead.

The aggrieved family members said they found the baby boy’s body on the floor and it had deep gashes around the neck and other parts. Sources said the hospital where the incident took place was unregistered and being run adjacent to a government hospital. As per the FIR lodged with Sadar Kotwali police, newborn’s father Ravi Kumar said he had admitted his wife Kanchan to the hospital on Monday and she was taken for a surgery the operation theatre.

After the delivery, Kanchan was shifted to the ward but the family was told that the baby would be shifted later. An hour later, the family was informed that the baby had died.

The family members then saw the hospital staff trying to chase a dog out of the operation theatre. They forced their way into the operation theatre and found the infant lying on the floor with several injuries on his neck. The police said that the baby’s body has been preserved for examination and autopsy.

Meanwhile, in two other sensational incidents, a brother duo were killed in Bijnore while a girl was allegedly raped by a teenager in Ballia and admitted to hospital in a critical condition. According to reports from Bijnore, Shivam (22) and Ashish (18) of Bankpur hamlet of Kiratpur in Bijnore disappeared under mysterious circumstances on Monday evening. Their father Devendra Singh and other family members searched for them and also reported the matter to local police. The matter took an ugly turn when on Tuesday morning, bodies of the brother duo were found lying in the nearby jungle of Gangawala.

The local police and family members rushed to the spot and found that one of the brothers had bullet injury while the other stabbed to death. The bodies of both the victims have been sent for the post-mortem and a team of forensic experts has been summoned to collect evidence from the spot. The family members were at a loss of words when asked about suspects. They claimed they had no major dispute with anyone.

In the Ballia incident, the victim had gone out to attend nature’s call on Monday when a 14-year-old boy raped her after taking her to a secluded spot, the police station in-charge said. She was admitted to a hospital where her condition was said to be critical. After the victim’s father lodged a complaint, an FIR was registered and efforts were on to nab the accused, the officer said.

Title: Swatantra Dev Singh set to be elected BJP state president
Article:
Swantra Dev Singh is set to be formally elected the president of BJP in Uttar Pradesh after the organisational polls on January 16. According to election officer and Urban Development Minister Ashutosh Tandon, the nomination process, including scrutiny and withdrawal, will be held on January 16 and, if required, polling and counting of votes on January 17.

As nomination will be filed only by present BJP president Swantra Dev Singh, he will be elected unopposed, sources said. During the election process, to be held at the state party headquarters here, the central party has appointed general secretary Bhupendra Yadav and former Bihar BJP president Mangal Pandey as observers. The filing of nominations will be held from 2 pm to 4 pm, scrutiny between 4 pm and 5 pm, and withdrawal between 5 pm and 7 pm on January 16. The new UP BJP president will be announced at 6 pm on January 16 after the time for withdrawal ends.

Title: ‘Take advantage of Govt schemes to help society’
Article:
Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik on Tuesday urged the ex-Servicemen to take advantage of the State Government’s schemes in the interest of the society as a whole.

Patnaik was addressing a meeting on the occasion of the Veterans’ Day. “I appeal to the veterans to take advantage of various schemes being offered by the Government of Odisha so that they can contribute to society as well as make their own lives better,” he said.

Calling the ex-Servicemen and veterans as an “extraordinary” community, Patnaik praised their selfless service to the nation at the prime of their age and sacrifices for ensuring the nation’s sovereignty and integrity.

This day has rightly been dedicated to Field Marshal KM Cariappa, the first Commander in Chief of Armed Forces of Independent India, who is a guiding beacon for serving as well as veteran soldiers, Patnaik said. The Chief Minister also commended the contributions of the 120 Infantry Battalion for its exemplary relief work done in the aftermath of Cyclone Fani in May this year.

Patnaik also paid floral tributes at the Martyrs’ Memorial and felicitated widows of five veterans who had participated in World War-II. He said the State Government is committed for the welfare of the ex-Servicemen and make use of their rich potential in the service of the nation.

Brig BP Pattanaik (Retd) gave the welcome address in which he offered the service of Ex-Servicemen in working for the betterment of the State. He also stated that the Veteran fraternity is a huge repository of diverse skills and experience which can be tapped for the overall development of the society and the State.

Brig SS Dhadwal, Commander Chhattisgarh and Odisha Sub Area, was present besides prominent senior war veterans of Odisha like Lt Gen NP Padhi, Lt Gen Nayaran Mohanty, Air Marshal JN Burma and Col HS Mohapatra.

Title: ‘Tanhaji’ declared tax-free in UP
Article:
The Yogi Adityanath government has given tax exemption to Ajay Devgn-starrer period film ‘Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior’. Devgn and his wife & actress Kajol thanked the CM for this move.

A government spokesman said here on Tuesday that the order to exempt state GST on the film based on the great Maratha warrior had been issued. “The decision was taken after producer & actor Ajay Devgn requested the state government to make the film tax-free in the state,” the spokesman said.

“The movie is a grand display of cultural pride and historical grandiose of the Marathas,” Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath said in a written statement. The Ajay Devgn-starrer details the ‘Battle of Sinhagad’ that was fought between Tanhaji Malusare, a military commander, under Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj and Uday Singh Bhan for the Kondana Fort. After a bitter duel between Tanhaji and Uday Bhan, the fort was reclaimed by the Marathas in the year 1670.

It was in this battle that Tanhaji Malusare had laid down his life while fighting Uday Bhan. In his honour, Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj had renamed the Kondana Fort as ‘Sinhagad’.

The decision of the government has also kicked up a political controversy as people are questioning as to why the government did not make ‘Chhapaak’ tax-free even though it is a movie based on acid attack victims.

‘Tanhaji...’ and ‘Chhapaak’ released at the same time across India. Many states like Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh declared ‘Chhapaak’ tax-free last week. Deepika has portrayed the character of Laxmi Agarwal, who is an acid attack victim.

Acid attack victims operate Sheroes Hangouts in Lucknow and Agra. In one of these outlets, Laxmi Agarwal met director Meghna Gulzar and the idea of ‘Chhapaak’ clicked. Therefore, it is said to be UP’s film.

“The decision to give tax exemption to ‘Tanhaji...’ seems to be a political one. ‘Chhapaak’ was ignored because Deepika Padukone had supported anti-CAA protesters and taken part in a protest at JNU. ‘Chhapaak’ is UP’s movie and it deserves tax exemption because it highlights the plight of acid attack victims,” Amarnath Agarwal, a senior Congress leader, said.

Title: Yoda’s sacred bones brought to Dhauli for burial
Article:
Two Japanese Buddhist monks from Osaka arrived with the sacred bones of Rev K Yoda, another Japanese Buddhist monk, who was the chief monk of the Dhauli Peace Pagoda and who passed away recently, here on Tuesday.

The two monks are Rev G Okonogi and Rev G Tanaka. The bones of Yoda will be buried at Dhauli, where his mother’s bones were buried in 1987.

Buddhist scholars Dr Bimalendu Mohanty, Dr Hari Patnaik and Mir Ajmat Ali were present when the monks arrived.

Title: Demolition of old deals
Article:
If Kerala has to survive as God’s own country, then it has to protect its fragile ecosphere from illegal development

The sight of four gigantic residential towers, built across a rich coastal ecosystem in Kochi’s Maradu, crumbling down like a pack of cards, was not just about the grossest violation of law but a cruel joke on home buyers. For they had invested their money as their unscrupulous realtors, believed to be in cahoots with local Government officials and politicians, made them believe their dream of living on a marina. And 10 years into their settled and charmed lives, all was gone. Though timely evacuation and appropriate compensation by the Kerala Government have provided some succour, it cannot be denied that they have been cheated and become gullible targets of the builder-administration nexus. It is in this sense that the Supreme Court’s demolition order, which was complied by the Kerala Government this week, serves as a deterrent in the real estate sector in the country in general, besieged as it is by corruption and malpractice. It also marks a paradigm shift in the way we treat our environment vis-a-vis development and becomes a template on what we should not do hereon. For Kerala, which has consolidated its tourism industry around the virginal and natural appeal of “God’s own country,” one that has triggered waterfront development, is at its worst phase of biosphere destruction. It is, therefore, imperative that its fragile balance be protected and made sustainable. The towers were situated on the shores of the Vembanad wetland, which strictly falls in the restricted zone under the provisions mandated by the Coastal Regulation Zone (CRZ). The limits set by the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change, which called for construction activities to be 50 metres away from the backwaters and mangrove forests and 20 metres away on islets, were flouted with impunity. According to the State Government’s own estimates, there are around 26,330 illegal buildings in 10 districts alone. As the dust of wrongdoings rises from the debris of the demolitions at Maradu, it’s not just the builders but political leaders responsible for the clearances, who must face the music.

The consecutive floods in the State have been indication enough of how illegal encroachments in the fragile backwaters have blocked the flow of natural waterways and forced a crisis every monsoon. This has already dented the tourism business badly, which contributes 12 per cent to the State’s GDP pie. The current demolition drive may force a number of projects to either scale down or shut shop altogether. With most resorts and hotels being built along river banks, they, too, may have to make changes. They must understand that undoing a wrong can prove more costly than a course

correction. And as much as land may be a challenge for the State, it just cannot afford shortcuts to jeopardise what sells most, its pristine coastline. The State seems to have got entangled in a web of its own making. A way has to be found out that involves reducing the over-dependence on tourism and looking at offsetting it with a boost to small and medium enterprises and setting up R&D and IT hubs. The alternative alone can wipe the grime of Maradu.

Title: Grow ideas to save farmers
Article:
As suicides continue unabated, India needs fresh strategies for mitigating risk, enhancing productivity, income and strengthening market linkages for businesses and cultivators

Farmer suicides continue to plague the country. According to the latest data released by the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB), 10,349 farmers committed suicide in 2018, which is only marginally less than the figures for 2016 when 11,379 cultivators took the extreme step. The figures for 2017 have been withheld in the report. Maharashtra leads the suicide list (17,972) followed by Tamil Nadu (13,896), West Bengal (13,255), Madhya Pradesh (11,775) and Karnataka (11,561).

Large swathes of cotton farms in central India have been the epicentre of a debt crisis that has gripped the rural population. For years now, this crisis has driven thousands of farmers to take their own lives. These suicides are not merely a loss of human lives, they are debilitating scars on our nation’s development canvas. While debates continue to rage on reforming the agricultural sector to improve the economic conditions of the growers, there has not been any attempt to focus on the possible psychological problems arising out of economic stress that may be leading to these actions.

For every cultivator who takes his own life, a family is hounded by the debt he leaves behind, typically resulting in children dropping out of school to become farm hands. Farmers’ suicides have to be tackled on several fronts and addressing mental health problems is just one of them but it is certainly a major part of the solution.

The lack of focus on marginal and sub-marginal farmers, tenants, sharecroppers, oral lessees and non-cultivator households has further compounded the agricultural conundrum. We need fresh thinking on strategies for mitigating risk, enhancing productivity and income and strengthening market linkages for businesses and farmers for better profits. Simplifying mortgage requirements and procedures, rationalising stamp duty for loans to small and marginal farmers and providing agricultural and business extension services in the farm and non-farm sectors respectively can go a long way towards providing resilience to the agricultural community.

Economic reforms and the opening of agriculture to the global market over the last two decades have made small farmers vulnerable to unusual changes and fluctuations. Small growers now have to compete with larger ones, who are well-endowed with capital, irrigation facilities and supplementary businesses to buffer them against any shocks. As a fallout, peasants are facing what has been called a “scissors crisis”, which is driven by the rising cost of inputs without a commensurate increase in output price.

Peasants take loans from moneylenders at exorbitant rates of interest in order to buy expensive transgenic seeds and high-cost fertilisers that allow them to merely feed themselves and their cattle. They hope for better yields in the future but this time never quite comes. Eventually, many farmers find themselves in a debt trap as they keep pursuing the vain mirage of a golden crop bonanza. Owing more than they earn, the steadiest of these workers have become gamblers at the highest of stakes, betting their land and their lives on a better crop. As debt mounts, many growers are now making a permanent escape from the physical and emotional pain by ingesting deadly pesticides.

There is an inextricable link between small holder farmers and the health of our planet, just as there’s a link between us and these small holder cultivators. They play a highly critical role in protecting the environment. Many small holder growers lack the resources they need to sustainably cultivate high-yielding, nutritious and marketable crops. The pressure to feed their families and sell their crops to pay off other debts means the soil is often overworked.

These cultivators have to be taught smart agriculture practices, like harvesting rainwater, using organic fertilisers and undertaking intercropping to preserve their soil. They must have access to more resources like small farm loans, real-time weather and pest updates. Information on accurate market prices for their crops can help them make the most of their farms all year-round.

Despite their vast numbers, small farmers are not a solidified group and have not developed their negotiating power. Social divisions among the rural population have been the main reason why rural voters have failed to push for policies that boost their incomes. The large size of this population and its heterogeneity limit its influence on public policy. Farmers’ refusal to give precedence to their economic interests over their other ethnic and caste loyalties have limited their influence over public policies.

The Government needs to revamp its services so that growers have access to the latest technology and field practices. Agricultural universities must be involved in creating tailored educational programmes that serve the diverse needs of the rural population. Peasants need to learn how to work with limited land in a productive and environmentally friendly way. They do not only need better plant species but also up-to-date guidance on how to grow them. They do not need high-tech tractors controlled by satellites but they do need access to regional databases that provide information on soil quality. They also need access to affordable capital so that they no longer pile up unmanageable debt loads.

Loan waivers are both “bad politics” and “bad economics.” Indebtedness is the most acute problem faced by small and marginal farmers. However, their borrowings are primarily from moneylenders and hence a loan waiver is not going to make any sense for them. It is the richer farmers who are the real beneficiaries of such populist policies.

The problems faced by small farmers are complex and require a ruthless political will to address them. Their landholdings are below the economically viable threshold — the result is the cyclical appearance of bad loans and poor rainfall. Loan waivers have little to do with ending the conditions that lead to such problems.

Debt relief programmes fail to provide assistance to landless farmers, who do not have access to bank loans and some other growers, who depend on money-lenders. The write-offs are a disincentive to the banking system because people have expectations of future waivers as well.

The borrowers see value in strategic defaults. While it is important for banks to make credit available to farmers so that they can leverage and do better, it is also important to maintain credit discipline.

Loan waiver schemes vitiate the credit culture and make it tougher for banks to continue lending to these segments. They create moral hazards in the financial system by rewarding those farmers who default on their loans, offering nothing to those who pay. They do not take into account the loans growers have taken from the informal sector. There is also no distinction between voluntary and involuntary defaults, so it actually rewards those that have willfully defaulted. Additionally, the scheme does not take into account climatic conditions and fertility of soil. Farmers in certain areas face a higher risk of crop loss on account of weather conditions.

One of the ways to promote a farm revolution and overcome the challenges faced by primary producers among small and marginal farmers is to design a livelihood and development strategy that entails collectivising and strengthening them through Food Producer Organisations (FPOs) and integrating them into an inclusive value chain. It offers end-to-end support to small farm holders. These mutual aid organisations, whose members pool their expertise and part of their savings, become self-propagating in course of time.

As the value chain stabilises, it could be upgraded to have a more-complete ecosystem of private and public-sector actors at every link in the value chain. Throughout this process, it is necessary for the farmers and FPOs to create an improved ecosystem in which secure, independent livelihoods become attainable for marginalised small farmers.

The underlying principle that the value chain follows is similar to that of the full stack approach. This approach makes the sponsor responsible for every part of the experience. Uber, for example, handles everything from connecting people with a driver to managing payment and ratings. In the context of agriculture, the full stack approach includes helping farmers identify what to grow and how to grow it, what technology to use and when and where to sell at what price.

While farmers continue to work out strategies to keep their age-old bond with their land alive, the new generation finds farming unsustainable. This is the key reason behind its influx to cities despite the hard truth that the new utopian world the migrants hope to discover is a mere chimera. India needs to arrest this influx and inject the rural economy with new skill development programmes to generate local employment. That is the right way of saving both the cities and villages.

(The writer is Member, NITI Aayog’s National Committee on Financial Literacy and Inclusion for Women.)

Title: Maintain your credit-worthiness
Article:
Boost your credit score by making timely payments and avoiding overspending. Financial discipline will help you stay out of a debt trap

Although money may not be the only important aspect of our lives, it is certainly a key one as it significantly lessens financial worries. This, in turn, enables us to have more control over our lives, freedom to carve our own path and fewer constraints on our choices. But many a time, we do not have enough finances to spare for some of our needs and that’s where banks and Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) step in to bridge this gap through credit or loans. And the amount of loan that we can get is directly proportional to our credit-worthiness. In simple terms, credit-worthiness is the extent to which a person or a company is considered suitable to receive financial credit, often based on their reliability in paying money back in the past.

Who measures credit-worthiness in India then? There are several credit bureaus or credit rating agencies (CRAs) that generate scores by maintaining historical information of the credits of an individual and business and generate reports. This information is gathered from different lenders and other financial sources and the reports generated by these CRAs have relevance for different banks and other financial organisations. This is because these reports help the banks and other lenders profile their customers and take better decisions before approving their loans or credit. There are six major CRAs in India, namely, Credit Information Bureau (India) Limited (CIBIL), Equifax, Credit Rating and Information Services of India Limited (CRISIL), ICRA, Experian and the CRIF High Mark Credit Information Services Private Limited, registered under the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI).

Among all, CIBIL is one of the most popular credit rating agencies in India. Its popularity is such that individual credit rating is known as the CIBIL score and people are really interested to know their CIBIL report.

An individual is scored on the scale of 300 to 900, where 300 is the lowest rating and 900 the highest. The higher the CIBIL score of a person, the greater are his/her chances of getting loans and credit cards easily. Some of the products offered by CIBIL are Credit Information Report, CIBIL TransUnion Score, Market Insight and so on. For organisations, one can get CIBIL Bureau Analyser, Portfolio Reports, CIBIL Company credit information report and so on. Most of the times it takes only one week to process the credit report from CIBIL. For any individual, maintaining a good credit score is vital if he/she wants to apply for loans or credit cards and it is important to stay in good standing. Here are some tips to achieve this:

Always pay on time: Timely payments of your debts are most crucial for having a high credit score. To stay on top of your payments, set up a calendar reminder or enrol in automatic payments. The on-time payment goal applies to all bills, including utilities, rent and cell phone service. Any missed payments can have an impact on the credit score for several years.

Pay all loans equally: Both revolving debt, like credit cards and long-term debt like mortgages or home loans, have an effect on the credit score. It is recommended that we should not prioritise one type of repayment over the other. It has been seen that having a high balance on the credit card over a long period of time lowers your credit score.

Old is gold: If you have a good payment track record, it adds to your credit score. So be very careful in wanting to close your old credit cards.

Pay in full: Making minimum payments on your credit cards is not advisable as this tends to drag the whole process, which in turn can lead to high interest payments. Try to pay in full whenever it is possible. However, if the minimum is all you can manage, make sure you pay at least that every month, otherwise you’ll have late or missed payments on your report.

Optimise your credit utilisation ratio: This is the ratio of credit card balance to the credit card limit. And the general thumb rule is to stay below 30 per cent for each card and on the overall basis (total balance on all cards divided by sum of credit limits). Credit utilisation ratio can improve by reducing the balances owed and maintaining or increasing the amount of credit available.

Follow a 20/10 rule: On a yearly basis, the credit card debt should not be more than 20 per cent of the total yearly income after taxes. And your monthly credit card payments should not be more than 10 per cent of your monthly take-home pay.

Make a repayment plan: If your debt is rising, take concrete actions. Stop using your cards and develop a monthly repayment schedule and most importantly, stick to it.

Overall, to maintain a good financial health and not suffer any financial distress, a disciplinary approach is very crucial. Boost your credit score by making timely and consistent payments and avoiding overspending. Financial discipline will go a long way to help you stay out of a debt trap.

(The writer is Associate Professor, Amity University, Noida)

Title: Collateral damage of political paranoia
Article:
All these shoot-downs of civilian jets by trigger-happy militaries around the world are fundamentally a political phenomenon, not a technical malfunction or mere human error

One of the main causes of death of airline passengers in recent decades is being shot down by somebody’s military. Not the very biggest, of course: Accidents account for nine-tenths of all deaths in civilian airline crashes and terrorist attacks and hijackings cause most of the rest. But a solid 2.5 per cent of the deaths are due to trigger-happy people in military uniforms.

That’s 1,379 passengers killed in commercial airliners that were shot down because they were off-course or simply mis-identified, out of a total of 57,767 deaths in all the “major incidents” (more than 50 deaths) in aviation history.

The first was an El Al plane that strayed into Bulgarian airspace in 1955. The second was an off-course Libyan airliner shot down by Israel over the Sinai Peninsula in 1973.

The last of the military shoot-downs in which actual fighters were involved was an off-track Korean Air jumbo jet shot down by a Soviet fighter in 1983. All 269 passengers and crew were killed.

Since then, the killing has been done by surface-to-air missiles, with no visual identification. The first of these was in 1988, when the US Navy ship Vincennes, operating illegally in Iran’s territorial waters, shot down an Iran Air jet bound for Dubai with 290 people aboard in the mistaken belief that it was a fighter plane. All aboard the ill-fated aircraft died.

Ukrainian Air Force missiles shot down a Siberia Airlines flight over the Black Sea in 2001 during a military exercise, killing 78 passengers and crew. In 2014, Russian-backed rebels fighting in eastern Ukraine shot down a Malaysian Airlines plane and killed all 298 passengers and crew.

And now 176 people, the great majority of them Canadian citizens or residents, have been killed just off the end of the runway in Tehran by a young Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps technician who thought he was shooting down an American drone. At least his commander acknowledged his personal responsibility — “I wish I was dead” — but the Iranian Government lied about it for three days.

Technically, this kind of mistake is inexcusable. You don’t even need high-cost military technology: A free Swedish app called Flight Radar 24 will give you real-time flight data on your phone for all civilian airliners in the air in your vicinity. What we are dealing with here is mostly human error. But, this human error is driven by paranoid politics and huge time pressure.

You can’t do anything about the time pressure: Decisions really do sometimes have to be made in seconds if you suspect that you have a “hostile” incoming on the radar and you have to protect your turf.

The paranoia might be easier to address in principle but it’s equally inevitable in practice: All the shoot-downs happen in countries that are in acute military confrontations of one sort or another.

And that’s the point, really. All these shoot-downs are fundamentally a political phenomenon, not a technical malfunction or mere human error.

We live in a far more peaceful world than our distant ancestors did but our deepest cultural traditions are still tribal. Once a confrontation gets going, we quickly turn into Yanomami villagers.

You can’t imagine an “accidental” shoot-down of a civilian aircraft over Canada nowadays, for example. Back in the Cold Days, however, there were surface-to-air missile systems in Canada, designed to shoot down Soviet bombers but perfectly capable of making the same sort of mistake that killed a plane-load of Canadians over Tehran last week. Nobody is invulnerable and nobody is immune to the paranoia.

On the other hand, don’t despair. The great majority of the world’s people now live in countries where the risk of war is very low or entirely absent, and the cities are not surrounded by anti-aircraft missiles. We have already travelled a very long way from the time when every human society lived in constant fear of all its neighbours.

This is still a work in progress. The past century has seen the most destructive wars in history — which was inevitable, given the growth in technology, wealth and population. But it was also the first time that people ceased to see war as natural, honourable and potentially profitable. Latterly warfare has gone into a steep decline.

There could still be back-sliding, especially if the climate crisis overwhelms us, but so far the trend line is promising. The world’s population has more than doubled in the past half-century but the number of people killed in war is less than a tenth of what it was in the previous half-century.

However, the planes are much bigger, and there are now around a million people in the air at any given moment, so there are also more people being killed in shoot-downs.

It’s never any consolation to tell people that things are getting better on average when they have been devastated by a personal loss. But for what it’s worth, they are.

(Gwynne Dyer’s new book is ‘Growing Pains: The Future of Democracy and Work.’)

Title: Maya’s b’day to be a low-key affair
Article:
Bahujan Samaj Party chief Mayawati’s birthday is going to be a low-key affair unlike previous occasions when Lucknow would assume a blue hue with party leaders and workers putting up hoardings and banners to wish her. BSP will be celebrating the 64th birthday of party president Mayawati on Wednesday.

Sources said that Mayawati, who has called a press conference on Wednesday morning, is expected to make some big political announcement related to Delhi and UP Assembly polls. The party leaders said on Tuesday that unlike every year, the celebrations would be a low-key affairs and that they would be celebrating the day as ‘ Jankalyankari Diwas’ as in the past.

After losing 2012 Assembly elections, BSP has been celebrating Mayawati’s birthday as ‘Jankalyankari Diwas’. “The party leaders help the needy, poor and handicapped. They also visit Dalit villages and hospitals to distribute fruits and blankets,” a senior BSP leader said.

It may be mentioned that the city used to turn blue every year as leaders would put up hoardings and banners on Lohia Path and near the BSP office and residence of Mayawati at Mall Avenue. However, this year, no such move has been made by the party leaders till now.

Party sources said on Tuesday that Mayawati would be in BSP office in Lucknow to celebrate her birthday with leaders and workers. Post afternoon, she will be heading to Delhi to spend time with her family. Mayawati will also release a party calendar and new edition of ‘A Travelogue of my Struggle Ridden Life and BSP movement- Vol 15’, penned by her, at the press conference. Mayawati shares her birthday with SP MP from Kannauj Dimple Yadav, wife of SP president Akhilesh Yadav, who will turn 42.

Title: 4-day ‘pathshala’ by Priyanka now from January 20
Article:
The proposed programme of Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra to hold four-day ‘pathshala’ in Rae Bareli from Wednesday (January 15) to train the newly-appointed district and city presidents of Uttar Pradesh was postponed on Tuesday.

UP Congress Committee incharge (administration) Sidharth Priya Srivastava said here on Tuesday that the training programme had been postponed and it ould be held from January 20. Srivastava said there might also be a change and now in the first two days, Priyanka and other senior leaders including state president Ajay Kumar Lallu will reveal the strategy to city and district presidents hailing from eastern UP and on third day, city and district presidents from western UP and eastern UP, along with all the officer-bearers of UP Congress Committee will attend the ‘pathshala’. On the last and fourth day, leaders from only western UP will attend the training session.

Sources said that Priyanka would update the leaders of party’s blue print of taking up public and other social issues to expose the state and Central governments. Priyanka had already interacted with the leaders before appointing them as district or city presidents. So far, she has appointed 108 district and city presidents from UP. The remaining 21, which include four district and 17 city presidents, will be announced before the training camp begins.

She will now guide them on how to spread party’s policies and at the same time, how to hold demonstration and protest to expose the failures of BJP governments both at the Centre and in UP.

During the training, besides taking updates on other party-related issues and policies, Priyanka will also discuss the strategy for the upcoming panchayat and graduate constituency polls. Besides Priyanka, some other experts raising social issues along with other senior leaders will also train the district and city chiefs. Ajay Kumar Lallu will also attend the camp.

It may be mentioned that to give a complete new look to the Uttar Pradesh Congress Committee preferring to go with the youngsters, Vadra already held a three-day ‘pathshala’ in Rae Bareli for the new office-bearers to spur revival of the party.

Interestingly, the entire committee consists of majority of names which were even unknown for the old Congressmen, so they are now terming it ‘Priyanka Gandhi or Lallu’s Congress’ in Uttar Pradesh. The new UPCC also, for the first time, got entry into the Gandhi bastion with the first training session and now the second ‘pathshala’ will be also conducted in Rae Bareli, the parliamentary constituency of party president Sonia Gandhi.

Title: Govt slams Akhilesh for insulting doctor on duty in Kannauj
Article:
The Uttar Pradesh government on Tuesday slammed former Chief Minister and Samajwadi Party president Akhilesh Yadav for publically humiliating a senior doctor at Kannauj Medical College.

Yadav, who was in Kannauj on Monday to meet those injured in the bus tragedy, asked a doctor to go out of the room and termed him an agent of the RSS and BJP.

Deputy Chief Minister Dinesh Sharma said it was an insult to the doctor who serves people. “The former CM’s act shows his upbringing and frustration, Sharma said on Tuesday. Health Minister Jai Pratap Singh also slammed the SP president for his outburst against the doctor.

“The SP president seems to have lost his mental balance. He appears to be suffering from a deep sense of frustration and it was the reason he insulted a doctor who was performing his duty,” the minister said.

Akhikesh had scolded senior doctor of Kannauj Medical College DS Mishra when the latter tried to explain that the government was giving orders to treat the injured. Dr Mishra also informed the former CM that the compensation announced by the government had been given to the patients.

When a patient said he didn’t get a compensation cheque, Dr Mishra tried to say the cheque had, in fact, been given. That was when Akhilesh lost his cool and asked the doctor to get out.

“You don’t say anything as you are a government servant. You are a small officer and you could be a RSS or BJP worker. But you can’t run away from your responsibility. Go away. Get out of here,” Akhilesh had told the doctor. Dr Mishra said he was in the room to treat patients.

A video showing Akhilesh scolding a doctor on emergency duty in Kannauj Medical College has gone viral on social media and some are calling out what they term arrogant behavior by the former UP Chief Minister.

At least 20 people were killed and several others injured when a private double-decker bus went up in flames after colliding with a truck in Kannauj last week. The government had announced an ex gratia of Rs 2 lakh each for the kin of those killed and Rs 50,000 each to the grievously injured. Akhilesh said the families of those killed in the bus tragedy would receive Rs 20 lakh if the Samajwadi Party was voted to power in 2022 UP Assembly elections.

Title: Odisha’s Patra appointed RBI Dy Governor
Article:
Odisha-born Michael Debabrata Patra was on Tuesday appointed as the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) for three years about six months after Viral Acharya resigned from the post.

Before Acharya, the post had been held by Urjit Patel, who was later elevated as the RBI Governor. Notably, Odisha-born Shaktikanta Das is now the RBI Governor since December last,

Patra is likely to take over the monetary policy portfolio, which was being handled by Acharya, being in the important monetary policy committee that takes decisions on the rate of interest.

Patra, a career central banker, was one of the candidates for the post who had been interviewed by the Finance Ministry panel headed by Banking and Finance Secretary Rajeev Kumar. His name was obviously ultimately cleared of the Prime Minister’s Office.

Title: 5 of family held in Cuttack in looting case
Article:
The Commissionerate police on Tuesday arrested five members of a family on the charge of stealing cash and valuables from a bank and a showroom in Cuttack city on zero night.

On basis of loot complaints filed by officials of the bank at Satichaura and staffs of a nearby showroom, police arrested Anil Das alias Ghantua. During investigation, police came to know that Anil’s mother, sister, wife and brother-in-law were his partners in crime and helping him in executing loot plans.

During the day time, women members of Anil’s family used to do recce of the targeted houses. Based on the inputs of the women folk Anil and his male relatives used to loot from those houses in late hours of night.

A police official said the family was also arrested in the past for their alleged involvement in other loot cases.

Title: Three IAS officers reshuffled
Article:
Chhattisgarh government has reshuffled three IAS officers on Tuesday including Bemetara district collector Shikha Rajput Tiwari.

As per the order, the 2008 batch IAS officer Tiwari was presently posted as Collector Bemetara has been appointed as Officer on Special Duty, District Gaurela-Pendra-Marwahi. As a special created post, from date of her joining the category has been declared as post for junior administrative pay scale of IAS.

Chhattisgarh Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel on August 15 last year had announced the formation of Gaurela-Pendra-Marwahi as the 28th district of the state. As per the announcement, the new district will formally come into existence on February 10, 2020.

Saurabh Kumar (IAS-2009), joint secretary, women and child development department who was also holding additional charge of joint secretary, school education department, has been shifted as Commissioner, Raipur Municipal Corporation.

Shiv Anant Tayal (IAS-2012) presently holding post of Commissioner, Raipur Municipal Corporation, has been shifted to Bemetara district as collector.

The GAD department order regarding transfer of the three IAS officers stated that prior permission has been sought from Chhattisgarh State Election Commission before issuing the order as the model code of conduct is in force in the state due to ensuing polls in panchayat.

Title: ‘Makar Sankranti big fest for tribals’
Article:
n Revenue and Disaster Management Minister Sudam Marndi on Tuesday thanked Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik for announcing Makar Sankranti a holiday.

“Tribals celebrate the Makar Sankranti in a big way. While Santals observe this festival in the name of Sakrat, Mundas call it Push Parab. I express my gratitude to the Chief Minster for respecting sentiments of lakhs of tribals and announcing the Makar Sankranti a holiday,” said Marndi, a tribal leader of Mayurbhnaj district.

He told reporters about the importance of mass ‘Asthi Bisarjan’ ritual held by tribals at Bhimkunda on the occasion of Makar festival, which would be held on January 20 and 21 this year.

Title: Naxals killed former associate’s brother
Article:
Naxals killed the younger brother of a former associate who is now working with police in Chhattisgarh's Dantewada district, police said on Tuesday.

Laxman Mandavi (26), a resident of Duvalikarka village, was stabbed to death with sharp weapons by ultras at his native place late Monday night, Dantewada Superintendent of Police Abhishek Pallava said.

Mandavi's brother quit the outlawed CPI (Maoist) last year and joined the police force, which apparently angered the rebels, he claimed.

As per preliminary information, over a dozen Naxals reached the village and then sent some lower rung cadres to bring Mandavi out of his house before killing him in a nearby forest, he informed.

Some villagers spotted the body on Tuesday morning and alerted the police who rushed to the forest. The body was sent for postmortem and later handed over to relatives, the official said. A manhunt was launched to nab the assailants, he said.

The deceased's elder brother Baman Mandavi, who was associated with Maoists since 2008, surrendered before police in October last year.

He was active as deputy commander of a military platoon of Maoists at that time and was carrying a reward of Rs three lakh on his head, the official said, adding that he later joined the police force in Dantewada.

"Naxals are losing their foothold and the trust of tribal people. Therefore, they are committing such crimes out of desperation and targeting relatives of their associates who have surrendered," Pallava said.

Some Maoist pamphlets were also recovered from the spot in which ultras warned to avenge the killing of their senior cadres - Varghese and Linga - in encounters by security forces, he said

Title: NMDC’s four Bailadila mines lease deed executed
Article:
NMDC Limited, India’s largest iron ore miner in public sector, executed and registered four of its Iron ore mining leases in Bailadila region of Dantewada district of Chhattisgarh namely Deposit-5, 10, 14 and 14 NMZ.

``These leases are executed for a period of 20 years from 2015 to the year 2035 with a combined capacity of 29 MTPA. This has been possible with cooperation extended by the Chhattisgarh government and especially Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel’’, a press release of the NMDC informed.

It further added, ``the Mining Lease areas for deposit-5, 10, 14 and 14 NMZ are 540.05 Ha, 309.34 Ha, 322.36 Ha and 506.74 Ha respectively’’.

``The Mining Lease deed execution was completed on January 10, 2020 and the registration formalities were completed on January 13, 2020. The total expenditure towards stamps duty and Registration fee of Rs.387 crore approximately is paid to the Chhattisgarh government,’’ the press release informed.

N. Baijendra Kumar, IAS, CMD, NMDC expressed his gratefulness to Chhattisgarh Government and Bhupesh Baghel and Senior officials of Government of Chhattisgarh for their `unstinted support’ to NMDC for ensuring uninterrupted iron ore supply to the Indian Steel Sector.

Title: 1,995 kg khichdi enters Guinness Book
Article:
Khichdi, a serving of beans and rice, weighing 1995 kilogram prepared by Department of Tourism and Civil Aviation Department of Himachal Pradesh entered in the Guinness Book of World Records on Tuesday at Tattapani in Mandi district.

The earlier record under this title was 918.8 kg, Chief Minister Jai Ram Thakur announced while addressing a gathering on the occasion of Tattapani Tourism Festival in Karsog area of Mandi district on Makar Sakranti.

Thakur appreciated the Department of Tourism for succeeding in their mission of cooking Khichdi of such volume.

He said that the Department has broken a record set earlier with a huge margin of about 1000 kg.

He said that due to construction of Koldam, the area has emerged as a major water sports destination of the State.

The Chief Minister said that Tattapani would be developed from tourism point of view as the area has immense potential of water sports.

President of Durga Devi Behari Lal Trust Ramesh Sood also welcomed the Chief Minister and other dignitaries present on the occasion.

Director Tourism and Aviation, Yunus said that the utensil used for cooking the Khichdi was 7x4 feet in radius and this attempt was aimed at bringing Tattapani on world tourism map.

Adjudicator of Guinness World Record announced that the Department of Tourism and Civil Aviation has set a World record by cooking 1995 kg Khichdi in a single utensil.

The Chief Minister also inspected the Water Sports Activity Demonstration and flagged off Tourism Circuit Bus of HRTC. He also enjoyed the ride of water jetty on the occasion.Thousands take dip in Himachal rivers on Makar Sankranti

PEOPLE DEFY WINTER CHILL, THRONG RIVERS FOR BATH

Braving the winter chill, thousands of devotees across Himachal Pradesh on Tuesday took holy dips in rivers to mark Makar Sankranti.

Since early morning the devotees were seen congregating at Tattapani, 55 km from the State Capital, and Manikaran, home to a Sikh shrine in Kullu district, for holy dips in the Satluj and Parvati rivers respectively.

Tattapani and Manikaran are known for hot water springs with high sulphur concentration.

The natural and prominent hot springs, which disappeared after the construction of the 800 MW Koldam hydroelectric power project executed by the National Thermal Power Corporation (NTPC) along the Satluj in Tattapani, have been restored.

Its reservoir had submerged the hot springs.

The devotees also visited Vashist temple, located on the outskirts of the popular tourist resort Manali.

The temple is situated on the left bank of Beas river, also known for its hot springs.

Title: Renowned nephrologists reach Supebeda
Article:
A team of renowned nephrologists from Bengaluru and Pondicherry visited Supebeda in a bid to detect the reasons causing deaths due to renal failures in the area. They were accompanied by experts from AIIMS, Secretary health department and others, on Tuesday.

“Renowned nephrologist Dr Vivekanand Jha, Dr Vijay Kher and doctors from AIIMS Raipur along with the Health Secretary Niharika Barik visited Supebeda and dealt with patients. The visit was quite promising. On Wednesday a meeting will be held wherein a consolidated action plan will be finalised,” Director AIIMS Dr Nitin Nagarkar said.

Meanwhile, poor residents of Supebeda informed that more than 300 patients consulted experts in the medical camp.

“Apart from Supebeda patients from neighboring villages had also arrived to consult the doctors,” Trilochan Sonwani a resident of Supebeda informed.

He further informed that the officials during the camp told villagers that the state government was seriously considering the possibility of availing portable dialysis units that could be installed in the houses for serious patients facing serious renal troubles.

According to Sonwani, four more patients are going to get themselves admitted in AIIMS Raipur and DKS Hospital due to deteriorating renal conditions.

Notably, Supebeda has hit headlines in recent months for deaths due to renal failure. As per government records more than 70 people have lost their lives due to kidney failure since 2008. However, so far, the exact reason causing death is yet to be ascertained.

Title: State ‘best’ in sports promotion
Article:
Odisha bagged the ‘Best State for Promotion of Sports’ award for the second time in a row at the Sportstar ACES Awards in Mumbai on Monday which Sports minister Tusharkanti Behera received.

Besides, Odisha’s para-badminton player Pramod Bhagat won the Sportsman of the Year (para-athlete) award and the State’s hockey player Deep Grace Ekka bagged the Sportswoman of the Year (Team Sports) award.

Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik said, “It adds another feather to Odisha’s cap and strengthens our resolve to transform Odisha into a global sports hub.”

Title: Banker’s mother holds dharna before PS
Article:
A day after a private bank DGM, accused of raping a college Lecturer after befriending her on dating application ‘Tinder’, was arrested and forwarded to court, his mother on Tuesday staged a dharna in front of the Chandrasekharpur police station opposing his son’s arrest and granting of bail to the girl.

The woman also threatened of committing suicide before the police station if the girl wasn’t arrested. “If both are accused in the incident, why the girl was released while my son was arrested?

Whatever happened between the two, it took place with mutual consent. If she was raped, why didn’t she move the police station the next day,” the woman questioned, adding that her son was kidnapped and thrashed.

Notably, the college Lecturer, was granted bail, the girl’s three associates were forwarded to court on Monday. Chandrasekharpur Police have registered case against the bank official under Sections 328 and 376 of IPC while the trio has been booked under Sections 365, 420, 120 (b), 379 and 34 of the IPC.

Title: State’s 1st Bloomberg Lab opens at XIMB
Article:
The Xavier Institute of Management Bhubaneswar (XIMB) and the Bloomberg, the global financial IT company, on Tuesday announced the opening of Odisha’s first Bloomberg Finance Lab at the XIMB campus.

State Finance Secretary Ashok KK Meena inaugurated the lab in the presence of XIMB Vice-Chancellor Dr Antony R Uvari and Registrar Prof EA Augustine. The XIMB joins more than 800 universities worldwide with Bloomberg Terminals or Finance Labs.

The Bloomberg terminal service is a seamlessly integrated solution that provides real-time and historical data, market moving news and analytics to help leading business and financial professionals worldwide make better informed investment decisions.

The service also features execution platforms for every asset class, research and a global network to communicate securely and reliably.

Bloomberg South Asia Regional Head Ashlesh Gosain said, “With the training and coursework offered by the Bloomberg Finance Lab, we hope to advance the careers of students across India, to build the next generation of financial professionals.”

Title: Youth Fest to be held annually, says Baghel
Article:
Chhattisgarh government will organise state-level Youth Festival every year. The event will be held to mark the birth anniversary of youth icon Swami Vivekanand.

Chief Minister Bhupesh Baghel made the announcement to this regard on Tuesday while addressing the concluding ceremony of the three-day fest held here at local Science College ground.

He also declared of awarding honorarium of Rs 500 to each of the participant in the fest.

About 7,000 artistes performed their art in 821 genres in the three-day long fest. Apart from folk songs and dance, traditional sports of the state were also put on display by the young talents.

In folk dance competition, Raipur districts' team was adjudged the first while Bilaspur and Dhamtari secured second and third positions respectively. Similarly in folk song competition, Rajnandgaon bagged the first prize while Gariaband and Raipur were declared the first and second runners up.

Title: SUDA meet: Urban women skill dev stressed
Article:
Housing and Urban Development, Panchayati Raj and Drinking Water and Law Minister Pratap Jena on Tuesday stressed on taking steps for strengthening women self-help groups (SHGs) in the urban areas and helping the members become self-reliant.

The Minister stated this while chairing the 20th management committee meeting of the State Urban Development Agency (SUDA) here. He asked officers to take steps for providing modern techniques to SHGs for production of different items that can be sold in competitive market in national and international level.

Issues relating to Deendayal Antyodaya Yojana-National Urban Livelihoods Mission (DAY-NULM), SMID, various services provided by WSHGs, Jala Sathi, Swachh Sathi, skill development training, different self-employment schemes, support to street vendors and survey on homeless were discussed at length.

Among others, H and UD Principal Secretary G Mathivathnan, Municipal Administrator Sangaramjit Nayak and SUDA Project Director Subhendu Kanungo and Additional Director Sharada Prasad Panda were present.

Title: BJP, Cong spar over spl assembly session
Article:
Chhattisgarh’s ruling Congress and opposition Bharatiya Janata Janata (BJP) have exchanged barbs over a scheduled daylong special session of state assembly convened on Thursday to ratify Constitution (126th amendment) Bill 2019.

A one-day session of Chhattisgarh Legislative Assembly (CLP) has been convened on January 16 for the ratification of bill to extend reservation for the scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribes. The Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha had passed the bill last month that required approval from at least 50 per cent states.

The reservation for both the categories is slated to end on January 25, 2020.

Being the first session of the calendar year, it would begin with the customary address of Governor. According to the business listed for the day in the Chhattisgarh assembly, the House would take the motion of thanks to Governor’s address and pass it the same day besides ratifying the Constitution (126th amendment) Bill 2019.

“The BJP has reservation over the period of session convened by the Congress government as discussion on motion of thanks to Governor’s address and passing it could not take place in one day,” senior BJP leader and former state’s parliamentary affairs minister Ajay Chandrakar said.

Since the opposition had to bring cut motion that would be printed and circulated, passing the motion of thanks in one day would not be practical, Chandrakar said. The party had demanded that the session should be extended. Though in most of the BJP-ruled states, a single day session was convened and ratified the bill.

A BJP delegation met Governor Anusuiya Uikey, Assembly Speaker Charandas Mahant and lodged their reservation recently.

Title: 6 months post polls, BJD still ahead of BJP, Cong
Article:
As the New Year 2020 unfolds, the BJD and the BJP are busy giving final shapes to their organisational election processes. The Congress is yet to take a call on party restructuring though the PCC president had hinted to take up the process in January.

The BJD is ahead of others in membership drive. For the first time, the party has adopted a deeper grass root cadre development approach. It has been identifying caders from the ward level and digitally documenting them. Huge work is going on at Assembly constituency levels. The BJD wants to make the party cader based and has targeted one crore membership. Party is forming its leadership structure form the ward, GP, Block/NAC, district to State cum Central Executive Body level.

Though party supremo and CM Naveen Patnaik shall be re-elected as the party president, there shall be competition for the State level vice president and general secretary posts as well as for the district level president posts. The BJD is likely to give important portfolios to its young generation.

However, Patniak, continues to be the only leader of the BJD on whose image the party survives. There is not yet emergence of any second line leadership in the BJD, who can win the trust of the voters.

Like the BJD, the BJP has almost completed its organisational election process in the State. Since it’s a national party, there is competition in the party for the State president post. The party has undertaken membership drive at grassroot and has completed its mandal and district leadership elections on consensus basis. The Central observers have visited the State and have taken feedback on the State president election.

The 2016 State party president election was west Odisha-centric and MLA centric. It is believed that the Central BJP leadership shall not repeat the incumbent for the State president post but shall give preference to a new leader.

There is obvious inquisitiveness about the new State BJP president. The party shall unlikely to spare its two senior leaders and Union Ministers, Dharmendra Pradhan and Pratap Sarangi for the president post now. It is not yet clear whether the Party shall give the post to a MP or a MLA or formet MLA or an organisational leader. Names of Suresh Pujari (MP), Aparajita Sarangi (MP) , Samir Mohanty (State VP), KV Singh Deo (former president) are making rounds for the State ’s top post. The party might choose a State leader who shall not only be able to expand the party’s organization network at grassroot but shall be able to operate in tune with the BJD-BJP mercurial relationship. The BJP shall also have to accommodate its new comers in various State and Central office bearer portfolios to check the repeat of Damodar Rout like incidents. Regional consideration may not be a priority this time.

The Congress had finished third in the last general election. The Assembly vote share of the party dropped from 25.7 per cent to 16.1 per cent. Many of its leaders defected to the BJP and the BJD. Even one of its working presidents left the party and joined the BJD during electioneering. Thus the last election destroyed the grassroot leadership system of the Congress in the State. The party needs full restructuring. It is not clear whether the Central Congress leadership shall allow the sitting PCC president to conduct the party restructuring process or shall put a new OPCC president to strengthen the party.

After the clean sweep of the BJD in the 2019 Assembly poll, the Opposition again got two opportunities to defeat the BJD in Patkura and Bijepur by-elections. But the BJD won these two polls. The BJD’s win in Bijepur Assembly by-election was important ,as the BJP had won the entire west Odisha Lok Sabha seats in the last general election. The by-elections re-established Patnaik’s popularity.

Today, six months after the general election, the BJD is still in a comfortable lead position in the State. There are two main reasons. First, the BJD is going ahead with new Government programmes. The BJD Government has lunched “ Mo Sarkar”, “5T”, “Mo Parivar” programmes to improve the quality of public service-administration. The State Government is also appreciated for not implementing the newly amended harsh MV Act in the State. The most popular programme of the State Government is its Jagannath Temple reform programme, lauded as” historic” by the Gajapati of Puri and millions of common people. The BJD Government has also undertaken a drive to remove the corrupt and inefficient officials from the State Government while awarding the good officers.

The second reason for the BJD’s dominance over the opposition parties is the party’s huge strength. The first contributing factor to the strength of the BJD is its internal discipline. Even, Prime Minister Modi has appreciated the discipline in the BJD. The dismal political fate of several dropped rebel leaders prevents the BJD leaders to undertake any divisive activities in party. The second factor for the growing strength of the BJD is its demand in the political market due to its repeated electoral success.

During the last election, the Congress and the BJP leaders who defected to the BJD, not only won the poll but also became Ministers in Patnaik’s Ministry whereas the leaders like Damodar Rout, Raghunath Mohanty and Baijayant Panda lost the 2019 election after leaving the BJD. The third factor for BJD’s growing strength is its presence at grassroots panchayat or ULB ward levels.

The fifth consecutive term pro-incumbency mandate for the Patnaik Government in Odisha shall be written as one of the regional political wonders in the political history of India. It should trigger a soul-searching exercise for the Opposition and the anti-BJD Government civil groups in Odisha.

Title: Hooda lashes out at BJP-JJPGovt for not declaring CMP
Article:
Former Chief Minister and the leader of opposition in the Assembly, Bhupinder Singh Hooda on Tuesday lashed out at the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and Jannayak Janata Party (JJP) -led coalition Government for not declaring its Common Minimum Programme (CMP) even after more than two months have passed after the formation of the government in the State.

Hooda alleged that coalition government in the State is directionless in the absence of CMP.

"Why is the coalition government in Haryana misleading the people by not declaring its common minimum programme," he asked.

Referring to Congress, NCP and Shiv Sena- led coalition government in Maharashtra, the senior congress leader said that soon after the formation of the government in the State, the coalition government in Maharashtra had released its CMP."Commo minimum programme of coalition government gives clarity in governance, he said", alleging that BJP-JJP led coalition government in Haryana is struggling to run the government effectively.

"They have failed to establish coordination among ministers... Ministers here are fighting over allocation of departments.” It seems there is no coordination inside the government.

This leads to confusion in governance and this coalition government may not continue for long time", he added.

The senior congress leader said that the party has decided to support the State government employees of their demand of implementation of old pension scheme.

Hooda said that he would raise this issue in the floor of Vidhan Sabha.

The senior congress leader said this after meeting with the representative of Pension Bahali Sangharsh Samiti.

Title: FIRs against 37 named, 675 unidentified persons in Giridih
Article:
Giridih town police have registered four FIRs against 37 people, and 675 unidentified persons for incidents of violence that took place in Giridih on January 12. The incident took place just about 1.5 km from the town police station.

A total of five FIRs have been lodged, out of which four FIRs have been lodged in the Town police station, while one FIR was lodged in Women’s police station. The FIR (1/20) was lodged on Monday at Women’s police station on a complaint by two minor girls namely Gullapa Praveen and Reshma Praveen under Section 354, 354B, 509, 34,and 8/12 POCSO Act, police sources said.

Police said that the first case lodged on complaint by District president of VHP Rajesh Kumar Arya against Saif Ali Gudu, Gulam Sarbar, Raja Aslam,Guran,Sonu Danis,Laddan Miyaand Sarfraz and 150, unnamed at Town police station. While the second FIR was lodged on Monday evening on a complaint by Shahnavaz Ahamd at same police station against Jai Prakash Verma, former MLA of Ganday, Kedar Hazra of BJP, MLA of Jamua and others.

Title: Police arrest 8 cyber criminals from Deoghar
Article:
Deoghar Cyber police conducted raid and arrested the prime suspect Gurudev Mandal at Kusmaha village under Khaga police station in Deoghar district in a cyber fraud case. Based on Mandal’s confession and further interrogation , seven more Cyber criminals were arrested from village Raghuwadih and Kusmaha.

The matter relates to Cyber Police Station case no 62/19, in which a victim Shubham Sandilya, medical student and resident of Deoghar was subjected to UPI fraud of Rs 50,000 after he received a fake call from a fraudster posing as manager of Bank of India. The arrested persons have been identified as Mijail Ansari, son of Khatir Ansari

Gurudeo Mandal son of Ramchandra mandal, Bhim Mandal, son of Ranjit Mandal, Rakesh Mandal son Ranjit Mandal all belonging to village Raguwadih, while Vijay Mahto and Ajay Mahto both sons of Supari Mahato, Samir Mandal son of Anil Mandal and Ganesh Mandal son Samir Mandal,resident of Kusmaha under Khaga, police station in Deoghar district.

Title: Schools caution against touts in Jamshedpur
Article:
Schools in the city are warning parents to beware of touts this admission season. Leading English medium schools have said that they are receiving complaints of parents falling prey to rackets involved in admission lure.

Admission touts are not uncommon in the city, where most reputable schools receive a far greater number of applications than they can accommodate. According to information, touts look for preys and promise admission saying they know certain ‘important’ people in the school and they can get admission. They ask for money (any amount ranging from 1 lakh to 5 lakhs) to get the admission done through the back door.

“We have witnessed cases where they print notices on false letterheads (supposedly given by the school ) giving information about interview dates, sale of books and uniform, orientation etc. These notices are forged and when parents go to the school for an interview or to buy books the school authorities deny them permission even to enter the school. Letters purportedly signed (forged) by the Principal, Secretary of the Managing Committee, bearing the school stamp are given to the parents. Needless to say these are all fraud,” said a school principal, who wished not to be quoted.

She said that feeding on the despair of anxious parents to secure admission in a good school for their child, there are a few touts/middlemen/fraudsters who take advantage of the situation to make a quick buck.

In a few cases, the child gets into the admission list by pure luck. But the touts tell the parents that it is because of their intervention that they have got the admission. The innocent parents are happy that their money has secured them admission. This is absolutely not true.

In a few rare cases the touts return the money (mostly it is not all, only a part) to the parents after three or four months when they are not able to secure admission for the child.

Father Pius Fernandes, principal, Loyola School said that the parents need to be careful. All the schools in the city follow a standard procedure for admission and the parents should not get lured to the touts.

“ Let me clear to the parents that no school takes money for admission. Therefore never ever give money to any middleman who promises admission. Even if he/she assures you that there is a 100 % chance of getting admission, do not believe him/her. All schools put up important information regarding admission on their school website. Therefore do not trust notices which do not have letterheads. Schools will not send notices through middlemen. Any notice will be given directly by the school office,” said an official.

Title: PIB holds workshop for orientation of folk artistes
Article:
A day-long orientation workshop for folk artists was organised here today with a view to spread wide publicity to promote Phase-2 vaccination of intensive Mission Indradhanush in various districts of Jharkhand by the Public Outreach and Communications Bureau, Ranchi, Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, Government of India. The workshop was inaugurated by Chief Guest Shailesh Kumar Chaurasia, Director, Department of Health and Family Welfare, Government of Jharkhand and Arimardan Singh, Additional Director General, Public Relations and Communications Bureau, Ranchi.

Chaurasia said, on the occasion, that malnutrition is very high in Jharkhand, vaccinating children will bring out the State by its vicious cycle. A healthy society is the first condition of the vision of a prosperous and strong country. He described folk artists as understanding the nuances of society, which keeps the complex matter between people in a simple and powerful way by communicating in the same language. He expressed confidence that the artists would play an important role in making the Rainbow Mission a success.

Arimardan Singh said that healthy children are successful human resources for the country, so keeping the health of children paramount, the government is running Mission Indradhanush at a broad level. He provided detailed information to the artists about various diseases related to the newborn like tetanus, rubella, measles, polio, tuberculosis, smallpox, plague etc. and related vaccines so that these can be included in their presentation and tell the people. He explained how vaccination is compulsory for all children as these diseases are spread by infection, so “if one child is left, the safety cycle is broken” is an important goal for this campaign.

The Immunization Officer of Jharkhand, Dr. Amar Mishra, informed that when the State was separated from Bihar, only 9 per cent vaccination was done here, which has increased to more than 90 per cent today. He said that in the Intensive Rainbow Mission Phase-2, it is the effort of the State that children and pregnant mothers, who are still deprived of vaccination should also be protected under it, so that the State can achieve the goal of 100 percent vaccination. The campaign was launched in four phases in the State on 2 December 2019. Each phase will be run for 7 days. The last phase will begin on the first Monday of March 2020. In the first phase, this campaign was carried out in 12,829 places, while in the second phase, vaccination campaign has been carried out in more than 8000 places so far.

At the same time, Dr. Vanesh Mathur of UNICEF elaborated on how to present the mission information to the people in a simple way. He said that 8 lakh children are being born every year in the state and there are around 9 lakh pregnant women, out of which about 20 per cent i.e. more than 1.5 lakh mother children are still out of this campaign, which is a serious issue. He gave information about various vaccines to be held in the Rainbow Mission.

Title: Baleswar urban traffic management in disarray
Article:
When the Road Safety Week is underway, the traffic management mainly in the Baleswar headquarters town and other urban pockets is in disarray.

In the headquarters town while none of traffic light posts is functioning for over 5 years, there is no proper marking for dividers or zebra crossing although traffic is being manned regularly in the busy hours at FM Golai, Station square , Police Line Square, ITI Square and Cinema Square.

As a result, the commuters face lots of inconveniences in the want of automatic traffic signaling. More difficulties are experienced by the denizens when there is load shedding during evening hours as the traffic police manning the traffic with manual signal with the marshaling wand is hardly visible.

Similarly, difficulties also arise for the traffic regulators when there is rain as the posts have no shed to accommodate the policemen.

Besides the infrastructure difficulties, the other bottlenecks are the parking and encroachments.
